awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Enforcement of Geofencing Policies for Commercial Unmanned Aircraft Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The adoption of services and applications that rely on Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) is expected to continue its acceleration for the foreseeable future. Such services and applications include search and rescue, crop monitoring, real-time traffic monitoring, critical infrastructure inspections, and others. As UAS continue to proliferate, aviation regulatory agencies around the world are facing a challenging dilemma in terms of safely integrating UAS operations into their respective national airspace systems and enforcing their compliance to relevant regulations, including enforcement of no fly-zones. Current UAS lack effective on-board flight restrictions that would prevent them from entering critical airspace, e.g., airport runways and nuclear power plants. Furthermore, it is essential that the safety and privacy of members of the public be safeguarded from accidental and non-accidental UAS incursions. This project aims to address these critical needs by developing offensive and defensive measures for detecting, identifying, and bringing down UAS that violate controlled/restricted airspace in an automated, controlled, and reliable manner.

A three phase approach to thwarting a UAS encroaching on restricted airspace will be used: (1) detect the incursion using passive radar that exploits signals of opportunity and radio frequency (RF) communications/emissions from the encroacher itself; (2) deploy one or more defender UAS, capable of learning the motivations and behaviors of the encroacher, to pursue the UAS and gain and maintain proximity to it even should the encroacher take evasive action; and (3) have the defender UAS launch offensive measures that manipulate/compromise the sensor and actuation signals the encroacher relies on to stay airborne.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the project was to develop a set of systematic approaches for countering the threat posed by nefarious or non-compliant UASs, through 1) reliable methods for the detection, identification, and localization of UAS in cluttered airspace and communication environments, 2) a robust and an adaptive learning framework to enable the pursuit and tracking of encroaching UAS, and 3) offensive techniques to influence sensing and actuation signals of encroaching UASs.

This project has contributed to the above goals by the following: 1)  developing low-cost radio-frequency (RF) communication-based secure vehicle motion (including location and velocity claims) verification schemes against active vehicles/UASs, which can broadcast false motion claims to evade detection;  2) developing a low-cost RF-based passive drone/UAS localization and tracking approach,  which leverages opportunistically reflected wireless signals emitted by existing infrastructure (such as cellular/LTE base stations) and a single wireless receiver; 3) demonstrating the feasibility of novel remote perception domain attacks against camera-based image classification for autonomous systems (including ground vehicles, surveillance systems, and UASs), either via creating non-existent/modifying existing objects with adversarial learning, or exploiting the imperfections/vulnerabilities of the sensing system design; and 4) developing systematic countermeasures to defend against the aforementioned attacks to prevent them from being used by malicious entities, either through model-based or learning-based attack detection approaches.  Experimental validation of the research has been done using software-defined radio based platforms and commercial-off-the-shelf camera sensors, and using either ground vehicles or quadrotor drones.

The project findings are expected to address some of the most critical issues that are hindering the integration of UAS operations into the national airspace system. Our results showed that it is possible to employ RF signals (either emitted from the target or environmental sources) to effectively detect, localize and track UASs/drones encroaching restricted areas or private households, which can be utilized as a low-cost alternatives/complements to existing commercially adopted high-cost methods (such as radars). In addition, it offers the defenders a non-intrusive way to bring down non-compliant UASs after detecting them, ultimately facilitating the widespread application of UAS geofencing techniques to ensure a safer commercial airspace.

This project has provided opportunities for research, teaching, and mentoring in the field of cyber-physical systems security, machine learning security, and physical layer security. The research outcomes have been widely disseminated through conference and online workshop presentations, and journal publications. The project efforts and funds contributed, in part, to the training of three Ph.D. students/Ph.D. dissertations in STEM areas. In addition, part of the project results have been incorporated into a graduate-level seminar course that the PI taught (advanced topics in information security), where recent research advancements on sensor attacks and adversarial machine learning were introduced.
